briefdescription.para: No mode - neither document outline nor thumbnail images are visible.
Fullscreen mode (no menubar, windows controls etc)

detaileddescription.para: The page mode

briefdescription.para: Display a single column of pages.
Display the pages in two columns, with odd-numbered pages on the left.
Display the pages in two columns, with odd-numbered pages on the right.
Display the pages two at a time, with odd-numbered pages on the left.
Display the pages two at a time, with odd-numbered pages on the right.

detaileddescription.para: The page layout
The render backends available

briefdescription.para: Lighter hinting for text when combined with TextHinting.
Enhance thin lines shape. Wins over ThinLineSolid.
Do not compose with the paper color.

detaileddescription.para: The render hints available

briefdescription.para: Adobe XML Forms Architecture (XFA), currently unsupported.

detaileddescription.para: Form types
Set a color display profile for the current document.

parameterdescription.para: is a cmsHPROFILE of the LCMS library.

detaileddescription.para: Set a color display profile for the current document.

parameterdescription.para: is the name of the display profile to set.

detaileddescription.para: Return the current RGB profile.

simplesect.para: a cmsHPROFILE of the LCMS library.

detaileddescription.para: Return the current display profile.

simplesect.para: a cmsHPROFILE of the LCMS library.

detaileddescription.para: Get a specified Page
Note that this follows the PDF standard of being zero based - if you want the first page, then you need an index of zero.
The caller gets the ownership of the returned object.

parameterdescription.para: the page number index

detaileddescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

The intent is that you can pass in a label like "ix" and get the page with that label (which might be in the table of contents), or pass in "1" and get the page that the user expects (which might not be the first page, if there is a title page and a table of contents).

parameterdescription.para: the page label

detaileddescription.para: The number of pages in the document
The type of mode that should be used by the application when the document is opened. Note that while this is called page mode, it is really viewer application mode.
The layout that pages should be shown in when the document is first opened. This basically describes how pages are shown relative to each other.
The predominant reading order for text as supplied by the document's viewer preferences.
Provide the passwords required to unlock the document

parameterdescription.para: the Latin1-encoded owner password to use in loading the file
the Latin1-encoded user ("open") password to use in loading the file

detaileddescription.para: Determine if the document is locked
The date associated with the document
You would use this method with something like: QDateTimecreated=m_doc->date("CreationDate"); QDateTimemodified=m_doc->date("ModDate");

The available dates are:
CreationDate: the date of creation of the document
ModDate: the date of the last change in the document

parameterdescription.para: the type of date that is required

detaileddescription.para: Get specified information associated with the document
You would use this method with something like: QStringtitle=m_doc->info("Title"); QStringsubject=m_doc->info("Subject");
In addition to Title and Subject, other information that may be available include Author, Keywords, Creator and Producer.

parameterdescription.para: the information that is required

simplesect.para: infoKeys() to get a list of the available keys

detaileddescription.para: Obtain a list of the available string information keys.
Test if the document is encrypted
Test if the document is linearised
In some cases, this is called "fast web view", since it is mostly an optimisation for viewing over the Web.
Test if the permissions on the document allow it to be printed
Test if the permissions on the document allow it to be printed at high resolution
Test if the permissions on the document allow it to be changed.

simplesect.para: depending on the type of change, it may be more appropriate to check other properties as well.

detaileddescription.para: Test if the permissions on the document allow the contents to be copied / extracted
Test if the permissions on the document allow annotations to be added or modified, and interactive form fields (including signature fields) to be completed.
Test if the permissions on the document allow interactive form fields (including signature fields) to be completed.

simplesect.para: this can be true even if okToAddNotes() is false - this means that only form completion is permitted.

detaileddescription.para: Test if the permissions on the document allow interactive form fields (including signature fields) to be set, created and modified
Test if the permissions on the document allow content extraction (text and perhaps other content) for accessibility usage (eg for a screen reader)
Test if the permissions on the document allow it to be "assembled" - insertion, rotation and deletion of pages; or creation of bookmarks and thumbnail images.

simplesect.para: this can be true even if okToChange() is false

detaileddescription.para: The version of the PDF specification that the document conforms to

parameterdescription.para: an optional pointer to a variable where store the "major" number of the version
an optional pointer to a variable where store the "minor" number of the version

detaileddescription.para: The fonts within the PDF document.
This is a shorthand for getting all the fonts at once.

simplesect.para: this can take a very long time to run with a large document. You may wish to use a FontIterator if you have more than say 20 pages

detaileddescription.para: Creates a new FontIterator object for font scanning.
The new iterator can be used for reading the font information of the document, reading page by page.
The caller is responsible for the returned object, ie it should freed it when no more useful.

parameterdescription.para: the initial page from which start reading fonts

detaileddescription.para: The font data if the font is an embedded one.
The documents embedded within the PDF document.

simplesect.para: there are two types of embedded document - this call only accesses documents that are embedded at the document level.

detaileddescription.para: Whether there are any documents embedded in this PDF document.
Gets the table of contents (TOC) of the Document.
The caller is responsable for the returned object.

In the tree the tag name is the 'screen' name of the entry. A tag can have attributes. Here follows the list of tag attributes with meaning:
Destination: A string description of the referred destination
DestinationName: A 'named reference' to the viewport
ExternalFileName: A link to a external filename
Open: A bool value that tells whether the subbranch of the item is open or not

Resolving the final destination for each item can be done in the following way:
first, checking for 'Destination': if not empty, then a LinkDestination can be constructed straight with it
as second step, if the 'DestinationName' is not empty, then the destination can be resolved using linkDestination()
Note also that if 'ExternalFileName' is not emtpy, then the destination refers to that document (and not to the current one).

simplesect.para: the TOC, or NULL if the Document does not have one

detaileddescription.para: Tries to resolve the named destination name.

simplesect.para: this operation starts a search through the whole document
a new LinkDestination object if the named destination was actually found, or NULL otherwise

detaileddescription.para: Sets the paper color

parameterdescription.para: the new paper color

detaileddescription.para: The paper color
The default color is white.
Sets the backend used to render the pages.

parameterdescription.para: the new rendering backend

detaileddescription.para: The currently set render backend
The default backend is SplashBackend
Sets the render hint .

simplesect.para: some hints may not be supported by some rendering backends.

parameterdescription.para: whether the flag should be added or removed.

detaileddescription.para: The currently set render hints.
Gets a new PS converter for this document.
The caller gets the ownership of the returned converter.
Gets a new PDF converter for this document.
The caller gets the ownership of the returned converter.
Gets the metadata stream contents
Test whether this document has "optional content".

Optional content is used to optionally turn on (display) and turn off (not display) some elements of the document. The most common use of this is for layers in design applications, but it can be used for a range of things, such as not including some content in printing, and displaying content in the appropriate language.
Itemviews model for optional content.
The model is owned by the document.
Document-level JavaScript scripts.
Returns the list of document level JavaScript scripts to be always executed before any other script.
The PDF identifiers.

parameterdescription.para: an optional pointer to a variable where store the permanent ID of the document
an optional pointer to a variable where store the update ID of the document

simplesect.para: whether the document has the IDs

detaileddescription.para: Returns the type of forms contained in the document
Destructor.
Load the document from a file on disk

parameterdescription.para: the name (and path, if required) of the file to load
the Latin1-encoded owner password to use in loading the file
the Latin1-encoded user ("open") password to use in loading the file

simplesect.para: the loaded document, or NULL on error
The caller owns the pointer to Document, and this should be deleted when no longer required.
The returning document may be locked if a password is required to open the file, and one is not provided (as the userPassword).

detaileddescription.para: Load the document from memory

parameterdescription.para: the file contents. They are copied so there is no need to keep the byte array around for the full life time of the document.
the Latin1-encoded owner password to use in loading the file
the Latin1-encoded user ("open") password to use in loading the file

simplesect.para: the loaded document, or NULL on error
The caller owns the pointer to Document, and this should be deleted when no longer required.
The returning document may be locked if a password is required to open the file, and one is not provided (as the userPassword).

detaileddescription.para: The available rendering backends.
The Document class represents a PDF document: its pages, and all the global properties, metadata, etc.

sect1.title: Ownership of the returned objects
sect1.para: All the functions that returns class pointers create new object, and the responsability of those is given to the callee.

sect1.title: Loading
sect1.para: To get a Document, you have to load it via the load() & loadFromData() functions.

In all the functions that have passwords as arguments, they must be Latin1 encoded. If you have a password that is a UTF-8 string, you need to use QString::toLatin1() (or similar) to convert the password first. If you have a UTF-8 character array, consider converting it to a QString first (QString::fromUtf8(), or similar) before converting to Latin1 encoding.

sect1.title: Rendering
sect1.para: To render pages of a document, you have different Document functions to set various options.

sect2.title: Backends
sect2.para: Poppler offers a different backends for rendering the pages. Currently there are two backends (see RenderBackend), but only the Splash engine works well and has been tested.

The available rendering backends can be discovered via availableRenderBackends(). The current rendering backend can be changed using setRenderBackend(). Please note that setting a backend not listed in the available ones will always result in null QImage's.

sect1.title: Color management support
sect1.para: Poppler, if compiled with this support, provides functions to handle color profiles.

To know whether the Poppler version you are using has support for color management, you can query Poppler::isCmsAvailable(). In case it is not avilable, all the color management-related functions will either do nothing or return null.
